customSqlDownload.title: Create new SQL download
customSqlDownload.notification: The easiest way to download and explore data is via the occurrence search user interface. But for complex queries and aggregations, the SQL editor provides more freedom.
customSqlDownload.sqlMachineDescriptionIntro: The SQL download was generated based on parameters provided by the user
customSqlDownload.countHigherTaxonomy: Occurrence count at higher taxonomic level
customSqlDownload.errorMinimumDimension: At least one dimension must be selected

help.whatIsThis:
This download format allows you to aggregate occurrences by their taxonomic, temporal and/or spatial properties. For example, a data cube can be configured to aggregate occurrences by family, month and grid cell of the European Environment Agency reference grid (three dimensions) and count the number of occurrences (a measure) per combination. The result is a CSV file.

Once configured, a SQL query will be created to generate the data cube. For more advanced use, it is possible to further customize the requested download by editing the SQL query.
help.dimensions: A dimension represents an aspect along which data can be aggregated. Selecting a higher resolution (e.g., species over family, date over year, 100 m over 10 km) will result in more categories and therefore more records.
help.taxonomicDimension: This dimension aggregates occurrences by their taxonomic rank.
help.temporalDimension: This dimension aggregates occurrences by time.
help.grid: This dimension aggregates occurrences in a spatial grid.
help.gridResolution: The size of each grid cell.
help.randomizePoints: For occurrence records with a coordinate uncertainty that covers more than one grid cell, should a random cell be chosen? If not, the cell containing the centroid of the record is used.
help.measurements: A calculated quantitative value for each combination of dimensions.
help.higherTaxonomy: Additional higher taxonomic ranks for which the number of occurrences should also be included. Useful to assert sampling bias.
help.minCoordinateUncertainty: The lowest recorded coordinate uncertainty (in meters). Useful to assert the spatial precision of the data.
help.minTemporalUncertainty: The lowest recorded temporal uncertainty (in seconds). Useful to assert the temporal precision of the data.
help.editSql: The easiest way to download and explore data is via the occurrence search user interface. But for complex queries and aggregations, the SQL editor provides more freedom.
